name: Southern River Terrapin
description: As a typical aquatic turtle, it has a flat shell and webbed toes. The tuntong has 4 claws on its front legs. Its head is elongated and pointed. During courtship, males develop an anthracite-black head with an arrow-shaped white patch on the throat, while females’ heads turn yellowish-white.
food_note: Fallen fruits, aquatic and muddy plants
image_alt: Southern river terrapin, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Shell length up to 65 cm; weight up to 35 kg
reproduction: Females lay 10–30 eggs up to three times per season, burying them in pits on beaches or sandy banks. Incubation lasts 69–112 days.
attractions: It rarely leaves the water, where it spends most of its life.
projects_note: Classified as a critically endangered species. Likely only about 200 individuals remain in the wild. In Europe, it is kept only at Prague Zoo.
breeding: Similar to the kalagur, one tuntong appeared at the zoo from 1973–1976, with additional individuals arriving in 2004 and 2005 in connection with the opening of the Indonesian Jungle pavilion, sourced from Plzeň Zoo.
